On Sunday, November 24, 2002, at 08:14 AM, Bill de h=D3ra wrote:
> One of t=
he main reasons I'm loyal to JPad pro is the fact that it
> will let me cre=
ate as many class templates as needed (I have well
> over a dozen for Java =
alone), including the boilerplate for test
> cases (if anyone here uses JPa=
d Pro and wants them, let me know).
>
> Other tools don't support this very=
 well and I don't understand why-
> I'm mainly thinking about Eclipse and I=
ntelliJ, but often when I say
> these IDEs don't do something, I get correc=
ted ;).

This will be no exception, then :)  IntelliJ IDEA has two kinds of=
 
templates, both of which could be useful for generating test cases. One 
=
type is a template for new files, and the other type is a template that 
ca=
n be inserted at any time (for example, I type "test" and hit "tab", 
and "=
public void test|() { }" is inserted for me (where "|" is the new 
location=
 of the text cursor)).

But I don't use it all the time, and I never use th=
e other type of 
templates for test case creation because the test cases ar=
e so simple: 
create a class, have it extend from TestCase, and insert some=
 testXxx() 
methods.


Erik
